questions.statement: Mr and Mrs Barton lived in the USA.
questions.explanation: They lived in a small seaside town in England, not in the USA.

questions.statement: Mrs Barton did not like to go for walks.
questions.explanation: The story states that Mrs Barton seldom went out with her husband and preferred to stay indoors, away from the cold.

questions.statement: There was a brass elephant on the stall.
questions.explanation: There was a brass monkey on the stall, not a brass elephant.

questions.statement: The stallholder had bought the mirror for two pounds.
questions.explanation: At the end of the story, we learn the stallholder bought it for only two pounds at a junk shop.

questions.statement: The photograph was worth a lot of money.
questions.explanation: It was the oil painting (not a photograph) that was worth a lot of money - about half a million pounds.

questions.statement: The painting was old and dirty.
questions.explanation: The painting was described as old and covered in grime, with details that were not clear.

questions.statement: Mr and Mrs Barton drove to the art gallery in their car.
questions.explanation: The story says they walked to the high street and went into an art gallery. They did not drive.

questions.statement: Mr Barton was eighty-two years old.
questions.explanation: The story clearly states that Mr Barton was eighty-two years old.

questions.statement: Mr Barton bought the frame for forty pounds.
questions.explanation: Mr Barton bargained and bought the frame for twenty pounds, not forty.

questions.statement: The stallholder claimed he paid ten pounds for the frame.
questions.explanation: The stallholder falsely claimed he had paid ten pounds for it himself.

questions.statement: Mr Barton's father had died when Mr Barton was only four years old.
questions.explanation: The story mentions that Mr Barton's father had died when he was only four years old.

questions.statement: The painting showed a scene of the seaside.
questions.explanation: The painting showed a shepherd with his flock resting under a large oak tree, with a small village in the distance.

questions.statement: Mr Barton treasured the portrait of his father more than life itself.
questions.explanation: The story states that there was one large portrait of his father which he treasured more than life itself.

questions.statement: The stallholder's wife was unhappy about the sale.
questions.explanation: The stallholder's wife smiled and said 'How wonderful!' when told about the profit from the sale.

questions.statement: Mrs Barton was very angry when she first saw the frame Mr Barton bought.
questions.explanation: Mrs Barton became very angry, took herself off to bed, and shouted that he could go out and buy his own dinner.

questions.statement: The oil painting was sold at auction for nearly half a million pounds.
questions.explanation: The story ends by saying the oil painting, in its original frame, was sold at auction for nearly half a million pounds.

questions.statement: Mr Barton found the stall the next day to return the mirror.
questions.explanation: The following day, Mr Barton walked up and down but could find no sign of the stall or the stallholder.

questions.statement: Mr Barton used a knife to lever the wooden back off the frame.
questions.explanation: The story says Mr Barton 'using a knife, levered the wooden back off the frame.'

questions.statement: The art gallery manager said the painting was by a very famous artist.
questions.explanation: The manager said 'this is a very famous painting, by a very famous artist.'

questions.statement: Mr Barton was not rich but he was not poor either.
questions.explanation: The story states 'he was not poor; but he was not rich either.'

questions.statement: The stallholder called Mr Barton a 'silly old fool'.
questions.explanation: The stallholder said 'Some people will buy any old rubbish. Especially when you tell them a sad story! Silly old fool, that man.'

questions.statement: Mr Barton put his father's portrait inside the frame before taking it to the gallery.
questions.explanation: Mr Barton put the painting to one side and placed his father's portrait in the frame, then forgot to put it back when he noticed the oil painting on the table.

questions.statement: The frame contained a hideous green and gold plastic flower-vase.
questions.explanation: The hideous green and gold plastic flower-vase was a different item on the stall that Mr Barton asked about to distract the stallholder.

questions.statement: About two hundred years ago, many famous painters had their paintings framed in frames just like the one Mr Barton bought.
questions.explanation: The manager explained that 'About two hundred years ago, many famous painters had their paintings framed in frames just like this one.'

questions.statement: Mr Barton's father was dressed in the uniform of a soldier in the portrait.
questions.explanation: The portrait showed an old man with a white beard and fine moustache, dressed in the uniform of a soldier.
